title: Which K-pop groups are considered as the fourth generation? - Quora

response.answer_text: The fourth generation hasn’t appeared yet. We’ll know when they’re here. I’ve been a fan of K-Pop for 20 years now, and while the other responses have gotten some points right, I don’t think any have hit the mark when it comes to answering your question. First, on the delineation of “generations,” some things to keep in mind: the boundaries are “soft”—new acts debut, other acts reach their heyday, other acts disband each year, so when someone says “the second generation began in 2007,” that’s an approximation with at least a couple of years of leeway. There can be overlaps between generations. And we don’t really know when a generation ends and a new one begins until we get a sense of it happening (like we did in the past couple of years when a wave of second generation groups disbanded).It’s probably better to consider an act’s heyday rather than their debut when identifying what “generation” they’re in. While some acts reach the limelight as soon as or even before they debut, others may take a few years, so even though they may have debuted within the time range of one generation, their most prominent work may place them in the next. The most prominent example of this may be EXID, whose 2012 debut may put them in the second generation chronologically, but since they didn’t get “put on the map” until their late 2014 breakthrough hit “Up and Down” and have since established a solid string of hits, they are better regarded as current generation artists.Shifts within generations and “waves/sub-generations” exist. While other responders to this question have chosen to regard certain eras as separate “generations,” and to some extent I agree, the fact is that in most discussions on the internet there is a consensus that there are just three generations, and in acceding to that, there should be an acknowledgement that there are smaller subdivisions between generations.That being said, when it comes to K-Pop fandom, it’s commonly understood that there so far have been three “generations” of K-Pop: First Generation: Mid 1990s-Mid 2000s. Starts with the founding of what is considered K-Pop (with the rise of Seo Taiji and Boys), through the co-ed pop groups (Cool, Roo’ra, S#arp), and continues through the era of the early idol groups (SES, HOT, Shinhwa, god, FinKL), the rise of BoA, and concludes with a sort of “Dark Ages” with the early idol groups disbanding and their successors (Black Beat, JTL, Sugar, MILK, Shinvi) meeting with less success, and the industry grappling with the rise of digital music distribution.Second Generation: Late 2000s to Early/Mid 2010s. Starts with the rise of TVXQ in conjunction with the TV aspect of “Hallyu,” and continues through the early “boom” of K-Pop. Super Junior. Big Bang. Wonder Girls. SNSD. KARA. SHINee. 2NE1. F(x). T-ara. Infinite. SISTAR. APink. IU. Girl’s Day. AOA.Third Generation: Mid 2010s to present. Starts with the rise of EXO. Continues through the rise of BTS, survival competition-assembled groups. Red Velvet. GOT7. Twice. GFriend. Mamamoo. Blackpink. Seventeen. NCT. Produce 101 groups (IOI, WannaOne, IZ*ONE) and affiliated acts.I believe we’re seeing the final wave of the third generation now, and in the next year or two we’ll see the groups that people will eventually consider the start of the new generation. I think the more sure sign of the rise of the fourth generation will be the early signs of the “aging” of the third generation—when groups like Twice and Mamamoo start having fewer comebacks each year and focus more on foreign promotions and solo efforts, for example.

some of these comments don’t add up. Anyone who tells you that 4th gen started in 2020 is wrong. To make it easier, senior groups are groups who’ve been active 5+ years. Groups are considered rookies for 2 years after debuting, and after the two years, they aren’t really called anything but they wait 3 more years to be called seniors. meaning that 4th gen literally started in late 2017. as you can see, the groups highlighted in red are semi-known or popular groups that are considered 3rd generation but debuted in early 2017  Some people may say i’m wrong but Wanna one and KARD are obvious late 3rd generation groups that debuted AFTER these groups. meaning that these groups HAVE to be considered 3rd gen also  But Oh My Jewel and The Boyz are groups that ALSO debuted in 2017 but CAN’T be considered 3rd gen. meaning that 4th gen began somewhere AFTER wanna one’s debut and BEFORE Oh My Jewel’s debut.  some of the people that also answered this question is saying that Stray Kids is 3rd gen. They are NOT. Stray Kids debuted in March 2018 which is AFTER the debuted of The Boyz.  they also literally STOPPED being considered rookies like 3 MONTHS AGO. you can’t be in 3rd gen and STOPPED being rookies not too long. and there was also someone who had said that 3rd gen groups are form 2012-present. they’re also wrong. i agree that 3rd started in 2012 but saying that the 3rd generation is from 2012-present is saying that groups who debuted in 2020 should also be considered as 3rd gen. Blackpink, Nct, and Wanna one are one of the final groups who marked the ending of 3rd gen. Itzy and Txt did not start 4th gen but they ARE apart of it. Stray Kids is an early 4th gen group but did not start the generation either. this is just me giving y’all a basic and clearer timeline of 3rd and 4th gen and debunking some of the bs some people had replied w.

I'd consider 4th gen kpop groups those who are shinning under the influence of Internet storm in kpop and well those who are within the bracket of the early 2000’s generation. They are actually a bit noticeable also in the international market way faster than 3rd gen kpop groups. With that said, here's some 4th gen groups that I consider. Stray Kidz  (G)I-dle  Ateez  Dreamnote  A.C.E.  And lastly just recent debut Itzy  When considering the waves of kpop, I mostly go between who are the promising that stands out after the biggest group of the last Gen. You'd even actually notice the huge influence of the big groups from last gen that is carried over to the debuting groups of the 4th gen. Needless to say, 4th gen kpop groups are taking advantages over the popularity of kpop as well as utilizing social media a lot more than when 3rd gen started. Another group to enter this batch if 4th gen is probably TXT

i think the 4th generation of k-pop is already happening. idk the exact years of it, but i guess the generation thing in k-pop is has a period of once every five years. they have the music that can typically be identified as typical of a particular generation of music. some say 2019 is the beginning of the fourth generation with the presence of itzy and txt. but in my opinion, knowing from the characteristic / uniqueness of music style, I can say that maybe nct is the beginning of the fourth generation, or the bridge between the third and fourth generations. some people also say that the same thing applies to shinee, because their debut time is like between the end of the second generation and the beginning of the third generation. I think the presence of NCT had a significant impact because their experimental music soon became a trend even a few years after they debuted. so I can say they are the pioneers of fourth generation. yeah i used the reference groups from sm entertainment in classifying k-pop generation. the first generation is h.o.t, shinhwa, and s.e.s. the second generation is dbsk, super junior, snsd, shinee, f (x). the third generation is exo and red velvet. fourth generation is nct (maybe).

A lot of people have different opinions, so I decided to try my hand at this. In my opinion, there is no way we are still in the 3rd generation. There is no way that groups like Itzy, Txt, Ateez, Stray Kids, etc are in the same generation as seniors like BTS, Mamamoo, EXO, Red Velvet, etc. A lot of people try to divide generations by time, but I’d have to disagree. Generations should be divided by trends and influence. In my opinion, the 4th generation started late 2017, with groups like The Boyz, who debuted on December 6, 2017. Leaving groups like Kard and NCT to be the last of the 3rd gen.

This is a short answer, but I don’t think there are any yet, I sorta see it as once the oldest few male idols from main groups have gone to the military, so like when, say, BTS J hope goes to the military, that’s when 4th gen starts for me, Idk though the boundaries are soft and imo it’s based on opinions

the leaders girl : itzy boy : tomorrow x together honourable mention everglow,gidle,ateez,ab6ix, cix,victon,verivery and i dont think stray kids is a 4th gen idols though but if they are they are the leaders alongside with txt
